projectPurpose: To provide a secure, fast, and general-purpose operating system kernel written in Rust that offers Linux-compatible ABI, serving as an alternative to the Linux kernel in security-sensitive environments while allowing the execution of unmodified Linux binaries.
mainFeatures: Written in Rust for memory safety

alternatives.name: Linux Kernel
mainFeatures: Widely adopted for servers, desktops, mobile, embedded

alternatives.name: MINIX 3
mainFeatures: Used for education and embedded systems

alternatives.name: Fuchsia (Zircon kernel)
alternatives.license: Open Source - BSD, MIT, Apache License 2.0
mainFeatures: Written in C++, C, Assembly, Dart, Go, Rust, Python

alternatives.name: seL4
mainFeatures: Focus on embedded and safety-critical systems

alternatives.name: macOS Kernel (XNU)
mainFeatures: Focus on user experience and performance

marketPositioning: Asterinas positions itself as a modern, security-focused alternative kernel for scenarios demanding Linux compatibility but requiring enhanced memory safety and a smaller Trusted Computing Base than the traditional Linux kernel. By leveraging Rust and providing a Linux-compatible ABI, it targets niche applications like Trusted Execution Environments (TEEs) where the ability to run existing Linux binaries is crucial, but the security and reliability offered by a Rust-based kernel with a reduced attack surface are paramount. This differentiates it from general-purpose OS kernels (Linux, Windows, macOS) and other research kernels (Redox, MINIX, seL4) that may lack the direct Linux ABI compatibility or the same emphasis on Rust-driven memory safety.
